Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2019 10:22AM Elephant wrote: Hi Kj: I also had very early stage IDC with a small mass. Recovery from the lumpectomy was very quick and easy. This was followed by 4 weeks of radiation where I had no side effects except that I started getting a little pink after the end of the treatment. The important first step is to connect with a surgeon that you feel comfortable with and take each step at a time.
Posts.Title: Anxiously awaiting results Kjchico

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2019 01:52PM Elephant wrote: I think that this is probably scar tissue, but I think that if you are concerned about it you should call your BS just for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: Firmness/Hardness in Lumpectomy Area 2.5 months post lumpectomy? kec1972 Volleyballmom2008

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2019 07:10AM Elephant wrote: I was selective in to whom I told the results of my biopsy. There were some people that I felt could not handle the news and would get too upset and I have not, to this day, told them. I did, however, focus on telling women so that they knew how important it was to go for regular mammographies as unfortunately there are still too many ladies who are afraid to go.
Posts.Title: Confused Sfllr Elephant

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2019 07:31PM Elephant wrote: My BS wanted the mammogram and ultrasound (but not the biopsy) redone at the hospital where I was having the surgery. The radiologist at the hospital saw more on the ultrasound than what was originally reported so then the BS wanted an MRI. I think that you should talk to your BS about your concerns and tell him that you want an MRI.
Posts.Title: Misdiagnosed sugarfoot75 L-O-R-I

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2019 08:10AM Elephant wrote: Djabi53 - I think that the only risk is that any breast cancer would go undetected because of the density. I have had this every time I had a mammogram so that it was always followed up with an ultrasound. My cancer was not detected on a mammogram, but the follow up ultrasound showed something that a biopsy confirmed was cancer. So in your case, it would probably be best to have a follow ultrasound to confirm that there is nothing there.
Posts.Title: Density question Djabi53 sweetp6217

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2019 12:18AM Elephant wrote: I think getting a drain is pretty standard. I had a drain in for 2 days only and went straight back to work.
Posts.Title: Recovery Time for Lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy? kec1972 kec1972

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2019 04:42AM Elephant wrote: Hi Cindr: my tumor was larger than yours and I am having total breast radiation on the left breast. They did a CT scan before to see where my organs were to calculate the angle for the radiation to avoid touching any internal organs. I looked at their computer modeling and I could see how they were having the radiation beam at an angle so that it was just on the breast. You should talk to your RO about your concerns, they were very patient with me wanting to look at their computer modeling before the radiation treatment started.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2019 12:21AM Elephant wrote: My oncologist said the same thing: that the pain may never disappear completely and that I may continue to feel slight pain and twinges for a long time.
Posts.Title: Pain in lumpectomy site years later Rachel1 mom2bunky

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2019 01:18PM Elephant wrote: Deb65: this is the worse time, knowing and not knowing. Once you get your treatment plan, you will feel so much better. I was a total mess until I had a definite plan and then I was anxious to get going with the treatment. It is not surprising that it is hard to wrap your head around all this, no one expects to get breast cancer and the news is a total shock. I remember one thing that kept me positive: a friend of mine who had been through this told me to remember that there will soon be a time when the last thing you think of at night and the first thing you think of in the morning will no longer be breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Today is the day Deb65 pingpong1953

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2019 11:34PM Elephant wrote: Jessie123: I have the same incision as you, same length and it does not actually go under the arm. I talked to my BS in the operating room just before surgery about the sentinel nodes and he showed me where they were which was not actually in the armpit but on the side. I am sure that they did not forget to take out the sentinel nodes, but just did it through one incision.
Posts.Title: incision for sentinel node removal? jessie123 leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2019 08:24AM Elephant wrote: I have had 16 rads and have 2 more left of the 5 boosts. Although most people report tenderness and redness, I have not experienced any effects from the rads at all. No changes either to the color or consistency of my breast. I agree that you should get a second opinion so that you are comfortable with your decision.
